questions.text: Arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals the following values: pH of 7.1 and HCO3- of 6 mEq/L. Assuming this is a case of metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis, what is the expected pCO2?
questions.solution:
The expected pCO2 value will be 17 mm Hg.

The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis, plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L - signifies metabolic acidosis. 

The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula: Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2.

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19. 

Alternatively,

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.25 mm Hg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.25 = 22.5

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22.5 = 17.5 mmHg (roughly ~ 17 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method is also used to assess compensation. However, Winter's formula is more accurate. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents with a sudden onset stabbing pain followed by diffuse abdominal pain and distension. He has a history of burning epigastric pain that is relieved by eating, and nocturnal pain for the past 5 months. His abdominal X-ray is as shown below. Which among the following is not associated with the pathology depicted in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain and distension and erect x-ray showing air under the diaphragm is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum due to duodenal perforation. Spinnaker sail sign is not seen in pneumoperitoneum.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

The other signs mentioned above are seen in the pneumoperitoneum caused due to hollow viscus perforation.

Duodenal perforation characterized by a sudden, sharp, stabbing pain is a known complication of peptic ulcer disease suggested by this patient’s history. The erect X-ray in pneumoperitoneum shows gas under the diaphragm. Other signs can be further divided into anatomical compartments in relation to the pneumoperitoneum:

Bowel related signs-

  • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign or bas-relief sign) - 50% of the cases have gas in the right upper quadrant adjacent to the liver, lying mainly in the subhepatic space and the hepatorenal fossa (Morrison’s pouch). When both the outer and inner walls of a bowel loop are visualized, it is known as Rigler’s sign.
  • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign) - The formation of a radiolucent triangle of gas around three bowel loops or two bowel loops and the abdominal wall. 

Peritoneal ligament related signs-

  • Football sign
  • Falciform ligament sign
  • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - It is visualized in the pelvis as a result of the free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

Right upper quadrant sign-

  • Morison's pouch sign (doge cap sign) - Air in the Morison pouch, bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant, presents as either a triangular-shaped, crescentic or semicircular lucency.
  • Cupola sign

The radiograph below shows a supine abdominal X-ray of a neonate with a large pneumoperitoneum. An oval lucency divided by the falciform ligament resulting in the so-called football sign is seen on supine film.

Given below is the supine abdominal radiograph of a patient showing pneumoperitoneum and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.

Gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It is seen as lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies. This is called the cupola sign. 

Supine abdomial X-ray given below shows cupola sign.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with an itchy rash along the extensor surface of her elbows, knees, and scalp. Examination reveals pink plaques with overlying silvery scales. She also has new lesions as shown in the image. The phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas is known as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image describe plaque psoriasis on the dorsum of the hand and isomorphic or Koebner phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas.

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants, or any treatment procedures. It is commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, lichen sclerosus, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and vitiligo.

Other option:

Option B - Development of lesions seen as a result of the spread of an infective agent (like Molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), is called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Option C - If a lesion disappears at the site of injury/trauma, then it is termed as the "reverse Koebner phenomenon". It has been documented in cases of psoriasis and vitiligo.

Option D - The isotopic phenomenon is the occurrence of a new skin disorder at the site of another healed skin condition. For example, the appearance of psoriasis at contact dermatitis or the appearance of granuloma annulare at the site of herpes zoster.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition and was started on treatment. When can the child's treatment be considered complete?
  1. There is no edema for at least two weeks
  2. There is no edema for at least 4 weeks
  3. Weight for length reaches - 2 S.D or higher
  4. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm
  5. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 13.5 cm
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 4.

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no edema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Treatment: The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Phases: 

Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal - Rehydration solution for malnutrition (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (4 mmol/kg/day) and magnesium (0.6 mmol/kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14 if there is presence of xeropthalmia.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding : Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal edema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured and her T-score is found to be -1.8. What does her T-score signify?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -1.8 signifies osteopenia. (T-score in osteopenia: -1 to -2.5).

Osteopenia refers to low bone mass with a T score of -1 to -2.5.

T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

Osteoporosis is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. 

A T-score of -1 or higher is considered normal.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text:
In a reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction test (RT-PCR), the target RNA strand that will undergo the process is 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3'. Outputs obtained from the process are shown below. Choose the correct statement.
  1. "A" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
  2. "B" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  3. "C" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  4. "D" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
questions.solution:
For the given RNA strand, 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3', the obtained complementary DNA strand will be as shown in image "C" following the rules of complementary base pairing (adenine binds with thymine/uracil and cytosine binds with guanine). The DNA strand obtained by replication of the cDNA strand will contain only thymine and not uracil and is therefore represented by "A" in the image above.

RT-PCR is a method that is used for the analysis of mRNA expression and its amplification.

Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a variant of PCR and includes 2 steps:

  • Generation of complementary DNA (cDNA copies) from mRNA using reverse transcriptase - used to qualitatively detect gene expression
  • Amplification of newly synthesized cDNA by traditional PCR - This can be quantitatively measured by using fluorescent dyes (qRT-PCR).

Uses: 

  • Determination of viral load
  • Screening of genetic diseases and cancers

questions.text: Which of the following suture techniques is employed for the best cosmetic appearance after wound healing?
questions.solution:
The suture technique employed for the best cosmetic appearance after wound healing is the subcuticular suturing technique.

Subcuticular sutures: 

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then they are gently pulled together. This wound cause approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured at the ends of absorbable sutures when they are used. When non-absorbable sutures are used, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

The following image is a pictorial representation of the subcuticular suture technique-

 

 

Other options-

Option (A): Continuous sutures-  the first suture is inserted similar to an interrupted suture. The rest of the sutures are made in a continuous manner till the other end of the wound. Constant tension should be maintained to avoid excessive tension or slack and hence the use of an assistant is helpful in this technique. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures-

 

Option (B): Mattress sutures - They can be vertical or horizontal and are used to evert or invert the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it helps to approximate wound edges when this would not be easily possible otherwise.

The following image shows the vertical mattress suture technique-

 

Option (C): Interrupted sutures- In this technique the needle should be inserted at right angles and exit at right angles to the skin. The distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound should be similar to the depth of tissue that is sutured. Twice this distance should be there between two consecutive sutures.

The following image shows interrupted suture-

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors help to signal the degree of joint rotation?
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor found in joint capsules and helps signal the degree of joint rotation are Ruffini's endings/Ruffini's end organ.

Ruffini's end organs are a type of slow-adapting receptor. They are located in the deep layers of skin and other internal tissues. They play a crucial role in signaling states where tissue deformation is continuous. These include deep touch which is prolonged and pressure signals. They are present in joint capsules as well and help in signaling the degree of joint rotation.

Other options:

Option A: Merkel discs are a type of expanded tip tactile receptors that cause the epithelium of the skin to bulge out creating a dome and are highly sensitive. They are hence grouped with touch domes. They play an important role in point discrimination, point localization, and determination of texture along with Meissner's corpuscles.

Option B: Meissner’s Corpuscles: They are encapsulated receptors found in the dermis of the non-hairy skin, most commonly on the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is very good. Their field of reception is very small and hence used for two-point discrimination. These are rapidly adapting receptors that encode Point discrimination, Precise location, Tapping, and Flutter.

Option C: Krause corpuscles are specialized sensory structures found within the genitalia and other mucocutaneous tissues and have been known to aid in thermal sensation. Recently, they have been shown to play a role in sexual behaviors in mice.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient comes to the medical outpatient department with increased frequency and burning micturition. He has a mechanical heart valve and is undergoing warfarin therapy for his transient ischaemic attacks. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity and he is started on antibiotics. The next day he comes with complaints of excessive bleeding after a trivial injury. Which of the following antibiotics was most probably prescribed?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing a man with a mechanical valve who is undergoing warfarin therapy presenting with excessive bleeding is most likely due to the administration of the antibiotic cotrimoxazole.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that inhibit the CYP2C9 enzyme, like cotrimoxazole, reduce the metabolism of warfarin and thus, enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin and increase the risk of bleeding.

Warfarin interactions:

Interactions with warfarin can be caused due to alteration in the absorption and metabolism of the drug, the circulating levels of clotting factors, and the state of epithelial surface.

Reduced efficacy:

  • Decreased absorption - COnjugation with cholestyramine
  • Increased clearance - CYP2C9 activation by drugs (barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin)
  • Reduced circulating volume - Nephrotic syndrome
  • Resistance - High Vitamin K consumption, High circulating clotting factor levels in pregnancy

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Options A and D - Tetracycline and Cephalexin (belonging to cephalosporins) are almost completely metabolized and excreted by the kidneys and hence do not interact with Warfarin.

Option C - Clindamycin is metabolized to N-demethylclindamycin and clindamycin sulfoxide, which are then excreted in the urine and bile. It does not cause CYP2C9 inhibition.

questions.text:
Match the following visual field defects with the site of the lesion

A. Optic radiations in the parietal lobe

B. Central chiasma

C. Optic radiations in the temporal lobe

D. Lateral chiasma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched lesions and their visual field defects are as follows:

Image 1 - B. Central chiasma
Image 2 - C. Optic radiations in the temporal lobe
Image 3 - A. Optic radiations in the parietal lobe
Image 4 - D. Lateral chiasma

Image 1: Bitemporal hemianopia due to lesion of central chiasma. The causes include tumors in the sella turcica region, suprasellar aneurysm pressure, and chronic arachnoiditis. It presents with bitemporal hemianopic paralysis of pupillary reflexes.

Image 2: Superior quadrantic hemianopia is also known as pie in the sky defect. It is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe. Lesions of the optic radiations spare pupillary reflexes and atrophy of the optic disc is not seen. The causes include vascular occlusions, primary/secondary tumors, trauma, and injuries sustained during lobectomy.

Image 4: Binasal hemianopia due to lesion of lateral chiasma. The causes include distention of the third ventricle, and atheromas of the carotids/posterior communicating arteries. It presents with binasal hemianopic paralysis of the pupillary reflexes.

Image 3: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia also known as pie on the floor defect. It is caused dues to parietal lobe lesions affecting the superior fibers of the optic radiations. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
Arrange the following patterns of obsessions seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in order from the most common to the least common:
  1. Pathological doubt
  2. Symmetry
  3. Intrusive thoughts
  4. Contamination
questions.solution:
In obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), the most common symptom patterns of obsessions seen in OCD are in the order Contamination > Pathological doubt > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviours are called compulsions, like counting, checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

Symptom patterns:

  • Contamination - This is the most common symptom pattern of OCD where objects are perceived to be contaminated followed by either washing or a severe compulsion to avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt—This is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession with doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door) and is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, whether the stove is turned off.
  • Intrusive thoughts - These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion and this is the third most common symptom pattern. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient disagrees with, which might lead to the patient reporting themselves to the police/confessing to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry—This is the fourth most common pattern, and it can lead to a compulsion to be slow. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

Diagnosis of OCD is by the presence of:

  1. Obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Time-consuming symptoms
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Symptoms not better explained by other mental disorders

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRI or clomipramine
  • Behavioural therapy: 
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioral and pharmacotherapy is found to be the most effective.

questions.text:
A patient presents with a sudden high-grade fever associated with chills and a productive cough for the past 3 days. A chest x-ray is taken which is shown below. The sputum is sent for culture and sensitivity. Arrange the following histopathological changes in the sequence of appearance during the course of this condition.
  1. Massive exudate containing neutrophils, RBCs, and fibrin
  2. Disintegration of RBCs and presence of fibrinosuppurative exudate
  3. Intra-alveolar edema containing few neutrophils and numerous bacteria
  4. Exudates containing granular, semifluid debris which is broken down by macrophages and fibroblasts
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of this patient showing high-grade fever, productive cough, and consolidation of the middle lobe of the right lung on chest x-ray is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia. The correct sequence of histopathological changes observed during the course of this condition is 3, 1, 2, 4.

Bacterial pneumonia is classified morphologically into lobular pneumonia and lobar pneumonia. Patchy consolidation of the lung is called lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia), while consolidation of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.

Stages of lobar pneumonia: 

Stages Duration Morphology
Stage I - Congestion 1-2 days

Gross: Heavy, boggy, and red

Histopathology: intra-alveolar edema fluid containing few neutrophils, and numerous bacteria.
Stage II - Red hepatization 2-4 days

Gross: Red, firm, and airless

Histopathology: Massive intra-alveolar exudate containing neutrophils, RBCs and fibrin
Stage III - Gray hepatization 4-8 days

Gross: Grayish-brown

Histopathology: Disintegration of RBCs and persistence of fibrinosuppurative exudate
Stage IV - Resolution 9-10 days Histopathology: Enzymatic digestion of exudate producing granular, semifluid debris which is broken down by macrophages or organized by fibroblasts growing into it.

Complications:

  • Lung abscess (common in pneumococcal or Klebsiella infections)
  • Spread to pleural cavity causing empyema or pleural fibrinous reaction to the underlying inflammation causing pleuritis.
  • Bacteremic dissemination to other sites of the body causes abscesses, endocarditis, meningitis, or suppurative arthritis.

Treatment:

Solely depends on the identification of the causative organism and administration of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

Related Pearl: Empirical Antibiotic Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Situation  Treatment Regimen
 Outpatient

Previously healthy:

 Macrolide / Doxycycline

Comorbidities:

Respiratory Fluoroquinolone 

      Or       

β-lactam + Macrolide / Doxycycline

Inpatients

Non - ICU

Respiratory Fluoroquinolone 

Or 

β-lactam + Macrolide / Doxycycline

Inpatients

ICU

β-lactam

+

Respiratory Fluoroquinolone Or Azithromycin

If Pseudomonas

 

 Anti-pseudomonal β-lactam

+

Fluoroquinolone* Or Aminoglycoside

+

Azithromycin

 
 

If CA-MRSA

Site based regimen

+

Linezolid Or Vancomycin

+

Clindamycin 

Note:

Macrolide - Azithromycin / Clarithromycin

Fluoroquinolones :

  • Respiratory Fluoroquinolone - Levofloxacin* / Moxifloxacin / (Gemifloxacin - only outpatient) 
  • Ciprofloxacin*

β-lactam :

  • Outpatient with comorbidities 
    • PO - Amoxicillin (+/- clavulanate)/ Cefpodoxime / Cefuroxime 
    • IV - Ceftriaxone
  • Inpatient, Non-ICU (IV) 
    • Ampicillin / Ceftriaxone / Cefotaxime / Ertapenem
  • Inpatient, ICU (IV) 
    • Ampicillin-Sulbactam / Ceftriaxone / Cefotaxime
  • Anti-pseudomonal β-lactam (IV) 
    • Piperacillin-Tazobactam / Cefepime / Imipenem / Meropenem 

Aminoglycoside - Amikacin / Tobramycin

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man drowns while on an arctic cruise by accidentally falling overboard with a horizontal entry into the sea. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death for this individual?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of immersion syndrome/ hydrocution/ submersion inhibition. Death results from cardiac arrest due to vasovagal inhibition followed by cardiac arrest.

Vagal stimulation occurs due to:

  • Stimulation of nerve endings of the surface of the body by cold water
  • Falling or diving into the water in a manner so that it suddenly strikes the abdomen, especially the epigastric region.
  • Stimulation of the nerve endings of the mucosa by the entry of cold water into the eardrums, nasal passages, the pharynx, and the larynx.

The mechanism involved in immersion syndrome:

  • Diving/falling into the water, feet-first
  • Inexperienced "duck-diving"
  • Diving/falling into the water with a horizontal entry

People under the influence of alcohol are more likely affected due to the general vasodilation of skin vessels, consequently amplifying the effects of vasovagal inhibition. These effects are increased in people who are attempting suicide/anxious as they have a more active reflex arc.

Option A: Cerebral edema is seen in cases of near-drowning. It is a type of atypical drowning and is also known as post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning. This type is necessitated by the survival of the drowning victim beyond 24 hours of a submersion episode. Death is due to respiratory decompensation suffered despite responding well to initial resuscitation measures. Mechanisms of death involve hypoxemia which results in sepsis, electrolyte imbalances, pulmonary edema, and cerebral edema. 

Option B: Pulmonary edema and cardiac arrest are the cause of death in typical drowning/primary drowning due to inhalation of water into the lungs. There are varying mechanisms for freshwater and saltwater drowning leading to either ventricular fibrillation or cardiac arrest respectively. Both types of typical drowning have terminal pulmonary edema and heart failure as mechanisms of death. 

Option D: In dry drowning death is due to the development of laryngeal spasm and subsequent airway closure. Thick mucus, foam, and froth may develop, producing a plug.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. She has not conceived despite having unprotected intercourse for the past 2 years. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices. On bimanual examination, a normal-sized nulligravid uterus is felt. A speculum examination reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s painful menses (dysmenorrhea), pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), lateral fornicial tenderness, bluish spots in the posterior fornix, and infertility suggest endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue at a site outside the uterine cavity. It is found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Endometriosis can present as blue or red powdered burned lesions on the cervix or posterior vaginal fornix, scarring around the tissue (puckered look). Other features include chocolate cysts causing left/right lower quadrant pain, pain during defecation, chronic pelvic pain and infertility, right lower quadrant pain, and cyclical hemoptysis.

Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. 'Powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis, as well as yellow-brown peritoneal fluid, can be seen on laparoscopy.

For minimal disease medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser and resection of endometrioma can be done. Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) to control pain .Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Option A- Chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) closely mimics endometriosis in its symptoms and signs. Both conditions produce pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and sterility. The uterus is retroverted and fixed. But in chronic PID, thickened and slightly tender fornices or a tubo-ovarian mass is noted and speculum finding as seen in the patient described above is not seen in chronic PID.

Option B - Rectocele is a form of genital prolapse seen frequently in menopausal women, especially those with a history of pelvic floor injury or multiparity. Patients present with varying degrees of prolapsed mass per rectum that needs splinting for a satisfactory bowel movement. 

 Option C - Adenomyosis, a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Aged> 40 years), is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus, leading to a symmetrically enlarged uterus (not more than 14 weeks size). Usual presenting features include menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea. Per vaginal exam findings are normal.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following marked blood vessels is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery which is represented by the marked blood vessel "3" in the given image.

Other blood vessels marked in the image are 

1 - Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery

2 - Tonsillar branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

4 - Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: You are appointed as a new member in National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) and have been assigned a district under your care. On checking the records for the number of HIV cases, you learn that the mean incidence over the last 8 years is about 46 cases per 1000 population. What is the prevalence of HIV in your jurisdiction?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the mean incidence (considering there are 46 cases per year) is given for 8 years which gives a prevalence of 368 cases per 1000 population.

Prevalence depends upon 2 factors, the incidence, and duration of illness. Given the assumption that the population is stable, and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as :

P = I x D

where,

  • P is the prevalence
  • I is the incidence
  • and D is the mean duration of the disease

In this case, I = 46 cases per 1000 population and D = 8 years. Therefore, P = 46 X 8 = 368 cases per 1000 population. 

The term incidence is defined as "the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time". It is represented by the following formula :

(Number of new cases of specific disease during a given time period / Population at-risk during that period) x 1000

The term "disease prevalence" refers specifically to all cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time, or over a period of time in a given population. It is represented by the formula :

(Number of existing cases of a specified disease during a given period of time interval / Estimated mid-interval population at-risk) x 100

The relationship between prevalence and incidence is represented by the formula used in the question. It shows that the longer the duration of the disease, the greater its prevalence

Tuberculosis is an example of a disease that has a high prevalence rate relative to incidence. This is because new cases of tuberculosis keep cropping up throughout the year, while the old ones may persist for months or years.

Similarly, if the disease is acute and of short duration either because of rapid recovery or death, the prevalence rate will be relatively low compared with the incidence rate

Prevalence rates are hence used to :

  • Estimate the magnitude of health/disease problems in the community, and identify potential high-risk populations
  • Prevalence rates are especially useful for administrative and planning purposes, e.g. hospital beds, manpower needs, rehabilitation facilities, etc

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who had recently been to the desert in the southwestern US presents with fever, cough, severe fatigue, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain.  On examination, erythema nodosum is noted. Tissue culture findings are as shown below. What is the most likely causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a flu-like illness, erythema nodosum, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain with a history of travel to south western USA and tissue culture showing spherules points toward the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis and the causative agent is Coccidioides immitis.

Coccidioides immitis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features occur due to an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias called desert rheumatism may also be seen. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Diagnosis:- Sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, and biopsy specimens are the samples used for diagnosis. Microscopy shows spherule with endospores. Culture on brain heart infusion agar with 5% blood shows white-coloured colonies and is the most specific for diagnosis. Serology using ELISA, Immunodiffusion assays, and complement fixation assays are also used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies. Delayed hypersensitivity can be demonstrated by a positive skin test with 'coccidiodin' (analogous to the tuberculin test).

Azole drugs such as fluconazole and itraconazole are the mainstay of treatment. Severe cases are managed with intravenous amphotericin B. 

Other options:

Option B: Paracoccidioidis brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis. It is a chronic ulcerative granulomatous disease of the skin and mucosa.

Option C: Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic pyogranulomatous infection involving primarily the lungs. Infection may resemble tuberculosis, or get disseminated to various parts forming multiple abscesses. A cutaneous form of the disease would present as a papule, with secondary nodules that coalesce and form ulcerative lesions.

Option D: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis. It is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system that is acquired by inhalation. It causes a pulmonary disease similar to tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane is scheduled to undergo a tympanic membrane grafting. Which of the following inhalational agents would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient undergoing tympanic membrane grafting is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air containing cavities as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence, it should be avoided in patients undergoing tympanic membrane grafting.

Other conditions in which nitrous oxide might be hazardous include:

  • venous or arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • pulmonary air cysts
  • intraocular air bubbles

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest branch of the artery marked in the image as 'X'?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the vertebral artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is its largest branch.

The vertebral artery is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery. It enters the skull through the foramen magnum and terminates by joining the vertebral artery on the opposite side forming the basilar artery. The branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery are:

  • Meningeal branches - supplying dura of posterior cranial fossa
  • Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
  • Anterior spinal arteries - supply the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.
  • Medullary branches - supplying the medulla

Clinical importance - A disruption in blood supply in the PICA leads to lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification of chronic kidney disease (CKD), end-stage renal disease is defined when the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) falls into which of the following categories?
questions.solution:
When GFR is less than 15 mL/min, it is classified as end stage renal disease.

End stage renal disease represents stage 5 of chronic kidney disease. It is characterized by accumulation of toxins and electrolytes which is normally excreted in the urine. GFR and urine output is severely compromised in this stage and patient is usually dependent on dialysis to improve renal functioning. 

Stages of Chronic Kidney Disease
Stage GFR(ml/min/1.73sq.mt) Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or increased GFR with laboratory evidence of kidney damage. Patient is asymptomatic
G2 60-89 Slight decrease in GFR, with laboratory evidence of kidney damage. 
G3A 45-59 Moderate decrease in GFR with clinical and laboratory evidence of kidney damage. Onset of anaemia
G3B 30-44
G4 15-29 Severe decrease in GFR, with or without other evidence of kidney damage. Prominent anaemia
G5 <15 Established renal failure, along with uremic syndrome.
